thread.title: Kenya: Cars Banned From Lamu Old Town, Only Donkeys, Ambulance to Operate on Island
thread.title_full: Kenya: Cars Banned From Lamu Old Town, Only Donkeys, Ambulance to Operate on Island

title: Kenya: Cars Banned From Lamu Old Town, Only Donkeys, Ambulance to Operate on Island
text:
Nigeria: Tipper Kills Two Pedestrians in Ota 
Timamy said the growing number of vehicles, motorcycles and bicycles being ferried into the island were not part of the heritage that is to be preserved by Lamu and are therefore not required since they are not allowed on the island. 
The Star observed that many parking lots on the island that previously housed vehicles, motorcycles and bicycles had been vacated and the vehicles missing, a sign that many had already been removed from the archipelago. 
Conspicuously missing from its usual spot was the County Commissioner's official land cruiser. 
Cargo boats were on Thursday and Friday spotted transporting some of the vehicles out of the island. 
Not a single vehicle was in sight on the narrow Lamu old town streets as of Friday morning. 
"We have no option but to remove our vehicles from here. Nobody wants trouble with the governor. It's obvious that if you don't to that, you will be heading to court.I wouldn't want to spend unnecessarily on court fines and all that. My car is now at Mokowe but I just hope it's safe there as it had been here,"said Seif Abass, a vehicle owner. 
Timamy said only donkeys and a select few vehicles would be allowed to operate on the island. 
Only the county Ambulance, a fire fighter van, two municipal tractors and three motorcycles attached to the KPLC, county government and the Ministry of Water offices respectively will be allowed to operate on the archipelago. 
Vehicles which shall be found on the island shall be impounded and their owners charged. 
Lamu old town is renowned worldwide as a region with rich cultural heritage and history having been listed by UNESCO in 2001 and prides itself for being one of the oldest and best preserved living settlements among the Swahili towns on the East African Coast. 
The Archipelago has however also been listed on the World Monument Fund Watch List as a site that is under threat from the forces of nature and modernity. Kenya
